title: what should I do about the Judgement that was just filed if I'm already paying monthly to the creditor
question: I was sued already by a creditor, I signed a consent form to pay 50.00 per month, I received a judgement which the same creditor I consented to pay 50.00 to I've been paying for I think it's been 4yrs now. Should I cont't to pay the 50.00 a month, Im very confused, I thought if I made payments to them they would not file a judgement against me.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Debt settlement,Bankruptcy and debt,Privacy law,Consumer protection,Fees,Personal information
answers: If you're current on the settlement agreement then there shouldn't be any grounds to sue or enter judgment. They may have broken the agreement which happens frequently because debt collectors have very poor accounting practices. You may also have an FDCPA (Fair Debt Collection Practices Act) case against the debt collector if they breached the settlement agreement. I would talk to an attorney and have your case reviewed.

Your first course of action is call and ask them for an accounting of the payments you made to them according to their records and then compare with your records. If you have PROOF by cancelled checks etc. that you have not breached the agreement and they recorded it anyway or in violation of the agreement, then ask them based on their mistake to immediately vacate the judgment and send you a copy and keep paying as agreed upon. Most agreements have an attorney clause provision in them too so if they are in violation you may possibly obtain back attorney fees incurred in establishing their breach of it.

Some persons though say the paid, have no proof, and no cancelled checks..sometimes the check disappeared but not cleared your bank. Or money order mailed never arrived! Thus, comes down to simple the contract and the evidence!

You should look at what I indicated and if you right, do as indicated so you don't incur attorney fees to proceed. Give them a date certain to reply ..but days should be enough. Good luck. PS..My son is moving to LA in 2 months!

I agree with the previous excellent answers. If you signed an agreement and have a copy get it out and read it. If it was a stipulated judgment that states they will only file if you miss a payment and you were late you may be stuck. Get the documents and payment history out and see a local lawyer right away. You may get them to vacate the judgment or have the court set it aside if they didn't follow the agreement.
You need to consult with a consumer protection or bankruptcy lawyer locally for private and specific advice on your particular issues.

Many lawyers on this site offer a free consultation and you can find one near you, make an appointment for legal counseling, and take your paperwork and a written chronological summary.
1. Keep a detailed log of all calls and letters and a paper file of all information. Because persistent violations of the FDCPA are punishable by statutory fines and attorney’s fees under federal law, but you need hard evidence.
2. Make a written demand that all further communications from creditors is in writing under 15 USC 1692 (c). The letter should also contain a dispute of the validity of the charges and include a demand for a complete accounting with signatures, and all contents of their file.
The creditor then has 30 days to reply and they may not take any action until you have been sent the validation. Bear in mind that this may be motivation for the collector to work your account when the file comes to them from the original creditor with new information pressure from the original creditor to collect.
3. Do not give them any personal information because that is how collectors decide on which accounts to recommend suing. Remember they may not tell the truth and will say just about anything to get a payment from you and that payment reaffirms the debt, gives them information about you and your bank and ability to pay.
4. If you are going to make payments use money orders only and never personal checks, wire transfers, money grams, or “check by phone.” If the collector finds a bank account, the collector will be more likely recommend a lawsuit to their legal department.
5. Collections are negotiable; the original creditor has given up and is losing up to 50% on the face value already either by splitting any return or selling at a huge discount. In addition, the costs of a lawsuit although discounted still are a factor in the decision to settle with you.
If you are going to settle mark the check “settled-in-full” at the very top back of the check and include a letter explaining that you are offering a settlement, keep copies of everything.
6. Get written confirmation of any payment plan the agency will accept before making a payment.
7. Specify in writing that all payments shall be applied to principle first.
If you’re ready to throw in the towel, go see a local bankruptcy attorney and explore your options for federal protection. The protection will even look back 90 days from filing, get back money taken by the collectors, and apply it fairly.

DO NOT use a paid debt settlement service; most of them are scammers.
Links to your rights; http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/edu/pubs/consumer/credit/cre27.pdf

http://www.credityoda.com/debt-validation-letter.html

Look for a qualified consumer protection attorney for a low cost or free consultation:
http://www.naca.net

Did you sign. Settlement agreement, or a consent to a judgment?

You need a collection DEFENSE attorney.
I think you should consult with an attorney immediately so that he or she can review your situation and see whether or not the creditor violated any laws.

If you have settled with creditor, settlement is binding, you have complied with terms of settlement, then, creditor must honor terms of settlement.
Carefully review terms of settlement agreement with debt collection defense counsel.
